revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name=Sir Dalrymple Arbuthnot, 5th Bt |birth_date={{birth date|df=y|1867|4|1}} |death_date={{death date and age|df=y|1941|3|31|1867|4|1}} |image=Arms Arbuthnot of Edinburgh (entire).svg |image_size=330 |caption= |allegiance={{UK}} |branch= [[File:Flag of the British Army.svg|23px]] [[British Army]] |rank=[[Brigadier-General]] |unit=[[Royal Artillery]] |birth_place= |death_place= |serviceyears= |battles= {{plainlist| *[[Chitral (princely state)|Chitral]] [[Chitral Expedition|Expedition]] *[[Second Boer War]] *[[World War I]] }} |awards= {{plainlist| *[[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]] (1915) *[[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] }} |relations=Son of Sir William Arbuthnot, 3rd Baronet |laterwork= }} [[Brigadier-General]] '''Sir Dalrymple Arbuthnot, 5th Baronet''', [[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]], [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] (1 April 1867 – 31 March 1941) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[baronet]] and officer.Memories: "Brig-General Sir Dalrymple ..." Burke's Peerage: "hon Brig-Gen 1920 RA." (meaning Royal Artillery) ==Early life== The second son of [[Sir William Arbuthnot, 3rd Baronet]] and Alice Margaret Thompson, and younger brother of the [[Sir Robert Arbuthnot, 4th Baronet|4th Baronet]], he served at the [[Royal Military Academy Woolwich]]. ==Military career== Arbuthnot was commissioned in the [[Royal Artillery]] on 17 February 1886. He served in the [[Chitral]] campaign of 1895 in the [[North-West Frontier Province (1901â€“1955)|North-West Frontier Province]], where he was awarded a medal with clasp, and the following year was promoted to [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] on 30 September 1896. He later served in the [[Second Boer War]] in [[South Africa]] from 1899 to 1902, being [[mentioned in despatches]]. He was promoted to [[Major (British Army)|major]] on 28 October 1901, {{ LondonGazette | issue = 27377 | startpage = 7396 | date = 15 November 1901 }} and in January the following year was appointed an assistant staff officer for colonial forces in South Africa.{{LondonGazette| issue=27427 |supp=|startpage=2693 | endpage=|date=22 April 1902}} By the time the [[First World War]] broke out he had risen to [[Lieutenant-Colonel]] and was Officer Commanding of the [[44th (Howitzer) Brigade Royal Field Artillery]], based at [[Brighton]]. On mobilisation, the Brigade formed part of the artillery of the [[2nd Division (United Kingdom)|2nd Division]] in the original [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]]. Arbuthnot commanded the Brigade until May 1915, when he became Commander Royal Artillery of the newly formed [[28th Division (United Kingdom)|28th Division]]. Although the [[Division (military)|Division]] spent only ten months on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] before re-deploying to [[Salonika]], it took part in several engagements at [[Second Battle of Ypres]] and in the [[Battle of Loos]]. Arbuthnot spent much of the rest of the war away from the Western Front. He was Brigadier General, Royal Artillery of the [[XII Corps (United Kingdom)|XII Corps]] at Salonika from January to July 1916, Commander Royal Artillery of the [[23rd Division (United Kingdom)|23rd Division]] in [[France]] and [[Italy]] from January 1917 to July 1918, and Brigadier General, Royal Artillery of the [[XXIII Corps (United Kingdom)|XXIII Corps]], Home Forces, from July 1918 to the [[Armistice]].[http://www.firstworldwar.bham.ac.uk/donkey/arbuthnot.htm "Dalrymple Arbuthnot"], by John Bourne In [[World War I]], he collected two medals and five clasps, being mentioned in despatches eight times, and being [[Brevet (military)|brevetted]] to command of the XII Corps in 1916.Memories: "served in 1914-18 War (despatches, Brevet-Colonel, CMG 1915, DSO 1918)". Burke's Peerage: "served in 1914-18 War (despatches, Brevet)." In the first years of the [[Second World War]], he served with the [[Civil Defence]]. Arbuthnot was honoured by the [[The Crown|Crown]] with the title of [[Order of St Michael and St George|Companion]] of The Most Distinguished [[Order of St Michael and St George]] (CMG) in 1915 and was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] (DSO). He was also a member of the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus]].Burke's Peerage 107th ed. and was made an Honorary Brigadier-General in 1920. Also had been a [[Justice of Peace]] for [[Shropshire]], he succeeded to his brother's baronetcy on 31 May 1916, when his brother was killed in the [[battle of Jutland]]. ==Family== On 15 January 1918, he married Alice Maud Arbuthnot, daughter of Hugh Lyttleton Arbuthnot. They had two children: *Major Sir Robert Dalrymple Arbuthnot, 6th Baronet (1919–1944) *Sir Hugh FitzGerald Arbuthnot, 7th Baronet (1922–1983) ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book | title= Memories of the Arbuthnots| author= Mrs P S-M Arbuthnot| year= 1920| publisher= [[Allen & Unwin|George Allen & Unwin Ltd]]}} *Burke's Peerage & Baronetage 1975 107th ed. *{{cite web | url= http://www.thepeerage.com/p12399.htm#i123985| title= thePeerage| accessdate= 2006-12-11}} ==External links== *[http://www.kittybrewster.com/members/k_1.htm Arbuthnot family tree] {{s-start}} {{s-reg|uk-bt}} {{succession box | title=[[Arbuthnot baronets|Baronet]]
'''(of [[Edinburgh]])| before=[[Sir Robert Arbuthnot, 4th Baronet|Robert Keith Arbuthnot]] | after=Robert Dalrymple Arbuthnot | years='''1916–1941}} {{s-end}}{{Arbuthnot family}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arbuthnot, Sir Dalrymple, 5th Baronet}} [[Category:1867 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich]] [[Category:Arbuthnot family|Dalrymple Arbuthnot]] [[Category:Baronets in the Baronetage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Royal Artillery officers]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Chitral Expedition]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Second Boer War]] [[Category:British Army generals of World War I]] [[Category:Companions of the Distinguished Service Order]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus]]
